publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday January 4, 2019 at 04:09

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers contain Felice Picano's writings, journals and diaries, and correspondence with his publishers and his friends, including American author Andrew Holleran.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Felice Picano Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Felice Picano Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call number: Uncat Za MS 282

bioghist.head: Felice Picano (1944- )
bioghist.p: Felice Picano, American author, editor, playwright, and activist, was born in New York in 1944; he graduated from Queens College in 1964.

Picano was affiliated with a literary group known as the Violet Quill, whose seven members, as men writing for men, are regarded as one of the strongest collective voices of the gay male experience in the post-Stonewall era. Authors Christopher Cox, Robert Ferro, Michael Grumley, Andrew Holleran, Edmund White, George Whitmore, and Picano met several times in 1979, 1980, and 1981 to read aloud from their works in progress. Also on the agenda were discussions of how they could work together to promote recognition, acceptance, and publication of gay literature beyond the boundaries of their own community. Of the VQ writers, Michael Grumley and Robert Ferro were the first to die from AIDS-related complications, both at age 46 in 1988, Grumley on April 28 and Ferro on July 11; they were followed by Whitmore in 1989 and Cox in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Felice Picano Papers contain writings, journals and diaries, and correspondence with his publishers and his colleague Andrew Holleran.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Writings, 1982-1987. II. Journals and Notebooks, 1970-1989. III. Correspondence and Financial Records, 1973-1989. IV. Other Papers, 1975-1991.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is arranged alphabetically by title of work, with miscellaneous writings at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains drafts and finished typescripts of novels, plays, screenplays, and other writings by Picano.

did.unittitle: "The Deformity Lover and other poems," typescript

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is arranged roughly chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains diaries, notebooks, and journals kept by Picano, some of which have drafts of his writings. The titles cited were assigned by Picano.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains a loose sheet of character descriptions.

scopecontent.p: Also contains lists of music and composers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is arranged alphabetically, with financial records at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series primarily contains correspondence between Picano and his publishers, his friends Andrew Holleran and Jean Harris, and his agent Jane Rotrosen.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV primarily contains issues of magazines kept by Picano. Also present is a small scrapbook with composed pages of clippings, photographs, and printed ephemera.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contains a typescript of "Automatons: a farce"
